q01.question: Suppose we wanted to sort a million integers where each integer is between 0 and 1,000. Which of the following statements are false?

responses.bubble_bigo: Bubble sort would order the integers in O(nlogn) time in the worst case.
responses.merge_bigo: Merge sort would order the integers in O(nlogn) time in the worst case.
responses.quick_bigo: Quick sort would order the integers in O(nlogn) time in the worst case.
responses.count_bigo: Counting sort would order the integers in O(nlogn) time in the worst case.
responses.insert_bigo: Insertion sort would order the integers in O(nlogn) time in the worst case.

q02.question:
Given the following vector in C++:

vector<int> v = {4, 6, 6, 3, 7, 5, 4, 7, 0, 1};

To sort the vector in ascending order we would do:

____(____, ____);

To sort the vector in descending order we would do:

____(____, ____);

q03.question:
Given the same vector in question 2, what would be the output of the following statements after sorting the vector in ascending order:

cout << lower_bound(v.begin(), v.end(), 4) - v.begin() << endl; // 1. ____
cout << upper_bound(v.begin(), v.end(), 6) - v.begin() << endl; // 2. ____

q04.question:
Complete the following implementation of binary search in C++:

template <typename IT, typename T>
bool binary_search(IT start, IT end, const T &target) {
    while (____) {                  // 1
        auto length   = ____;       // 2
        auto middle   = ____;       // 3
        auto midpoint = *(____);    // 4

        if (____) {                 // 5
            end   = ____;           // 6
        } else if (____) {          // 7
            start = ____;           // 8
        } else {
            return true;
        }
    }
    return false;
}
